question: Please Derek
answer: Do read it, do!

question: They'll be wrapping fish in it in the morning so I guess it's not a total waste.
answer: Cynic!

question: Don't get me wrong  I'm glad it'll do well for you, Derek. All right, but I can't start listening to the critics, and I can't kid myself about my own work. A writer writes from his gut, and his gut tells him what's good and what's... merely adequate.
answer: Well I don't pretend to be a critic, but Lord, I have a gut, and it tells me it was simply marvelous. You dog!

question: I thought you were going to join us. Jesus, Garland, you left me alone with those people.
answer: Don't panic, I'll join you in a minute. What's you think of Richard and Poppy?

question: The play was marvelous. She wept, copiously. Millions of dollars and no sense.
answer: We have to talk a little business. I've just been on the phone to Los Angeles. Barton, Capitol Pictures wants to put you under contract. They've offered you a thousand dollars a week. I think I can get them to go as high as two.

question: To do what?
answer: What do you do far a living?

question: I'm not sure anymore. I guess I try to make a difference.
answer: Fair enough. No pressure here, Barton, because I respect you, but let me point out a couple of things. One, here you make a difference to five hundred fifty people a night  if the show sells out. Eighty five million people go to the pictures every week.

question: To see pap.
answer: Yes, generally, to see pap. However, point number two

question: I don't know, Garland; my place is here right now. I feel I'm on the brink of success-
answer: I'd say you're already enjoying some.

question: No, Garland, don't you see? Not the kind of success where the critics fawn over you or the producers like Derek make a lot of money. No, a real success  the success we've been dreaming about  the creation of a new, living theater of, about, and for the common man! If I ran off to Hollywood now I'd be making money, going to parties, meeting the big shots, sure, but I'd be cutting myself off from the wellspring of that success, from the common man. ...I guess I'm sprouting off again. But I am certain of this, Garland
answer: Okay Barton, you're the artist, I'm just the ten percenter. You decide what you want and I'll make it happen. I'm only asking that your decision be informed by a little realism  if I can use that word and Hollywood in the same breath. ...Look, they love you, kid  everybody does. You see Caven's review in the Herald?

question: No, what did it say?
answer: Take my copy. You're the toast of Broadway and you have the opportunity to redeem that for a little cash  strike that, a lot of cash. ...The common man'll still be here when you get back. What the hell, they might even have one or two of 'em out in Hollywood.

question: ...That's a rationalization, Garland.
answer: Barton, it was a joke.

question: Welcome to the Hotel Earle. May I help you, sir?
answer: I'm checking in. Barton Fink.

question: F-I-N-K. Fink, Barton. That must be you, huh?
answer: Must be.

question: Okay then, everything seems to be in order. Everything seems to be in order. ...Are you a tranz or a rez?
answer: Excuse me?

question: Transient or resident?
answer: I don't know... I mean, I'll be here, uh, indefinitely.

question: Rez. That'll be twenty-five fifty a week payable in advance. Checkout time is twelve sharp, only you can forget that on account you're a rez. If you need anything, anything at all, you dial zero on your personal in-room telephone and talk to me. My name is Chet.
answer: Well, I'm going to be working here, mostly at night; I'm a writer. Do you have room service?

question: Kitchen closes at eight but I'm the night clerk. I can always ring out for sandwiches. ...Though we provide privacy for the residential guest, we are also a full service hotel including complimentary shoe shine. My name is Chet. ...Okay
answer: Huh?

question: Okey-dokey, go ahead.
answer: What

question: Don't you wanna go to your room?!
answer: ...What number is it?

question: ...Six-oh-five. I forgot to tell you. ...Those your only bags?
answer: The others are being sent.

question: I'll keep an eye out for them. I'll keep my eyes peeled, Mr. Fink.
answer: ...Six, please. Looking at the picture

question: ...Six, please. Looking at the picture
answer: How d'ya like your room!

question: ...Who is this?
answer: Chet!

question: ...Who?
answer: Chet! From downstairs! ...How d'ya like your room!

question: It's not as bad as it looks; just a mosquito in my room
answer: Place okay? ...Where did we put him?

question: I'm at the Earle.
answer: Never heard of it. Let's move him to the Grand, or the Wilshire, or hell, he can stay at my place.

question: Thanks, but I wanted a place that was less...
answer: Less Hollywood? Sure, say it, it's not a dirty word. Sat whatever the hell you want. The writer is king here at Capitol Pictures. You don't believe me, take a look at your paycheck at the end of every week  that's what we think of the writer. ...so what kind of pictures does he like?

question: How's about it, Bart?
answer: To be honest, I don't go to the pictures much, Mr. Lipnik

question: That's okay, that's okay, that's okay  that's just fine. You probably just walked in here thinking that was going to be a handicap, thinking we wanted people who knew something about the medium, maybe even thinking there was all kind of technical mumbo- jumbo to learn. You were dead wrong. We're only interested in one thing
answer: ...Yes, thank you.

question: Lou. ...He used to have shares in the company. An ownership interest. Got bought out in the twenties  muscled out according to some. Hell, according to me. So we keep him around, he's got a family. Poor schmuck. He's sensitive, don't mention the old days. Oh hell, say whatever you want. Look, barring a preference, Bart, we're gonna put you to work on a wrestling picture. Wallace Beery. I say this because they tell me you know the poetry of the street. That would rule out westerns, pirate pictures, screwball, Bible, Roman... But look, I'm not one of these guys thinks poetic has gotta be fruity. We're together on that, aren't we? I mean I'm from New York myself  well, Minsk if you wanna go way back, which we won't if you don't mind and I ain't askin'. Now people're gonna tell you, wrestling. Wallace Beery, it's a B picture. You tell them, bullshit. We don't make B pictures here at Capitol. Let's put a stop to that rumor right now. ...Thanks Lou. Join us. Join us. Talking about the Wallace Beery picture.
answer: Excellent picture.

question: We got a treatment on it yet?
answer: No, not yet Jack. We just bought the story. Saturday Evening Post.

question: Elbows on his desk, he looks down at what he has just written. He rolls the paper up a few lines, looks some more. After a beat he rolls the sheet back into place. as he continues typing. He stops after several more characters and looks.
answer: The picture of the girl on the beach.

question: Staring, as the end-of-the-tether laughing continues. Barton looks back down at his typewriter as if to resume work, but the sound is too insistent to ignore.
answer: The empty hallway, a pair of shoes before each door. At the end of the hall a dim red bulb burns over the door to the staircase, punctuating the sick yellow glow of the line of wall sconces.

question: Hello... Chet? This is Barton Fink in room 605. Yes, there's uh, there's someone in the room next door to mine, 604, and he's uh... He's uh... making a lot of... noise. ...Thank you.
answer: Did you... Somebody just complained...

question: No, I didn't  I mean, I did call down, not to complain exactly, I was just concerned that you might  not that it's my business, but that you might be in some kind of... distress. You see, I was trying to work, and it's, well, it was difficult
answer: Yeah. I'm damn sorry, if I bothered you. The damn walls here, well, I just apologize like hell... ...My name's Charlie Meadows. I guess we're neighbors...

question: Barton Fink.
answer: Neighbor, I'd feel better about the damned inconvenience if you'd let me buy you a drink.

question: That's all right, really, thank you.
answer: All right, hell, you trying to work and me carrying on in there. Look, the liquor's good, wuddya say? ... You got a glass? It's the least I can do.

question: Okay... a quick one, sure...
answer: Yeah, just a nip. I feel like hell, all the carryings-on next door.

question: That's okay, I assure you. It's just that I was trying to work
answer: What kind of work do you do, Barton, if you don't mind my asking?

question: Well, I'm a writer, actually.
answer: You don't say. That's a tough racket. My hat's off to anyone who can make a go of it. Damned interesting work, I'd imagine.

question: Can be. Not easy, but
answer: Damned difficult, I'd imagine.

question: And what's your line, Mr. Meadows?
answer: Hell no! Call me Charlie. Well Barton, you might say I sell peace of mind. Insurance is my game  door-to-door, human contact, still the only way to move merchandise. ...In spite of what you might think from tonight, I'm pretty good at it.

question: Doesn't surprise me at all.
answer: Hell yes. Because I believe in it. Fire, theft, and casualty are not things that only happen to other people  that's what I tell 'em. Writing doesn't work out, you might want to look into it. Providing for basic human need  a fella could do worse.

question: Thanks, I'll keep it in mind.
answer: What kind of scribbler are you  newspaperman did you say?

question: No, I'm actually writing for the pictures now
answer: Pictures! Jesus! ...I'm sorry, brother, I was just sitting here thinking I was talking to some ambitious youngster, eager to make good. Hell, you've got it made! Writing for pictures! Beating out that competition! And me being patronizing! ...Is the egg showing or what?!

question: That's okay; actually I am just starting out in the movies  though I was pretty well established in New York, some renown there,
answer: Oh, it's an exciting time then. I'm not the best-read mug on the planet, so I guess it's no surprise I didn't recognize your name. Jesus, I feel like a heel.

question: That's okay, Charlie. I'm a playwright. My shows've only played New York. Last one got a hell of a write-up in the Herald. I guess that's why they wanted me here.
answer: Hell, why not? Everyone wants quality. What kind of venue, that is to say, thematically, uh...

question: What do I write about?
answer: Caught me trying to be fancy! Yeah, that's it, Bart.

question: Well, that's a good question. Strange as it may seem, Charlie, I guess I write about people like you. The average working stiff. The common man.
answer: Well ain't that a kick in the head!

question: Yeah, I guess it is. But in a way, that's exactly the point. There's a few people in New York  hopefully our numbers are growing  who feel we have an opportunity now to forge something real out of everyday experience, create a theater for the masses that's based on a few simple truths  not on some shopworn abstractions about drama that doesn't hold true today, if they ever did... ...I don't guess this means much to you.
answer: Hell, I could tell you some stories

question: And that's the point, that we all have stories. The hopes and dreams of the common man are as noble as those of any king. It's the stuff of life  why shouldn't it be the stuff of theater? Goddamnit, why should that be a hard pill to swallow? Don't call it new theater, Charlie; call it real theater. Call it our theater.
answer: I can see you feel pretty strongly about it.

question: Well, I don't mean to get up on my high horse, but why shouldn't we look at ourselves up there? Who cares about the Fifth Earl of Bastrop and Lady Higginbottom and  and  and who killed Nigel Grinch-Gibbons?
answer: I can feel my butt getting sore already.

question: Exactly, Charlie! You understand what I'm saying  a lot more than some of these literary types. Because you're a real man!
answer: And I could tell you some stories

question: Sure you could! And yet many writers do everything in their power to insulate themselves from the common man  from where they live, from where they trade, from where they fight and love and converse and  and  and... so naturally their work suffers, and regresses into empty formalism and  well, I'm spouting off again, but to put it in your language, the theater becomes as phony as a three dollar bill.
answer: Yeah, I guess that's tragedy right there.

question: Frequently played, seldom remarked.
answer: Whatever that means.

question: You're all right, Charlie. I'm glad you stopped by. I'm sorry if  well I know I sometimes run on.
answer: Hell no! Jesus, I'm the kind of guy, I'll let you know if I'm bored. I find it all pretty damned interesting. I'm the kind schmoe who's generally interested in the other guy's point of view.

question: Well, we've got something in common then.
answer: Well Christ, if there's any way I can contribute, or help, or whatever

question: Sure, sure Charlie, you can help by just being yourself.
answer: Well, I can tell you some stories ...And look, I'm sorry as hell about the interruption. Too much revelry late at night, you forget there are other people in the world.

question: More please.
answer: I'm a writer, Mr. Geisler. Ted Okum said I should drop by morning to see you about the

question: Ever act?
answer: ...Huh? No, I'm

question: We need Indians for a Norman Steele western.
answer: I'm a writer. Ted O

question: Think about it, Fink. Writers come and go; we always need Indians.
answer: I'm a writer. Ted Okum said you're producing this Wallace Beery picture I'm working on.

question: What!? Ted Okum doesn't know shit. They've assigned me enough pictures for a goddamn year. What Ted Okum doesn't know you could almost squeeze into the Hollywood Bowl.
answer: Then who should I talk to?

question: Get me Lou Breeze. Lou? How's Lipnik's ass smell this morning?... Yeah?... Yeah?... Okay, the reason I'm calling, I got a writer here, Fink, all screwy. Says I'm producing that Wallace Beery wrestling picture  what'm I, the goddamn janitor around here?... Yeah, well who'd you get that from?... Yeah, well tell Lipnik he can kiss my dimpled ass... Shit! No, alright... No, no, all right. ...Okay kid, let's chow. Don't worry about it. It's just a B picture. I bring it in on budget, they'll book it without even screening it. Life is too short.
answer: But Lipnik said he wanted to look at the script, see something by the end of the week.

question: Sure he did. And he forgot about it before your ass left his sofa.
answer: Okay. I'm just having trouble getting started. It's funny, I'm blocked up. I feel like I need some kind of indication of... what's expected

question: Wallace Beery. Wrestling picture. What do you need, a road map? ...Look, you're confused? You need guidance? Talk to another writer.
answer: Who?

question: We boom down to show the blue serge pants and well-polished shoes of the stall's kneeling occupant.
answer: He quickly straightens and goes to the sink. He starts washing his hands. We hear the stall door being unlatched.

question: The stall door opening.
answer: Quickly, self-consciously, he looks back down at his hands.

question: His hands writhing under the running water. We hear footsteps approaching.
answer: Forcing himself to look at his hands. We hear the man reach the adjacent sink and turn on the tap. He gives a nervous smile  more like a tic  and looks back down at his hands. We hear the man gargling water and spitting into the sink. Looks back down, then up again.

question: Barton Fink. ...Jesus. W.P.!
answer: I beg your pardon?

question: W.P. Mayhew? The writer?
answer: Just Bill, please.

question: Bill!... ...You're the finest novelist of our time.
answer: Why thank you, son, how kind. Bein' occupied here in the worship of Mammon, I haven't had the chance yet to see your play ...Yes, Mistuh Fink, some of the news reaches us in Hollywood.

question: Sir, I'm flattered that you even recognize my name. My God, I had no idea you were in Hollywood.
answer: All of us undomesticated writers eventually make their way out here to the Great Salt Lick. Mebbe that's why I allus have such a powerful thrust. ...A little social lubricant, Mistuh Fink?

question: It's still a little early for me.
answer: So be it.

question: ...Bill, if I'm imposing you should say so, I know you're very busy  I just, uh... I just wonder if I could ask you a favor... That is to say, uh... have you ever written a wrestling picture?
answer: ...You are drippin', suh. ...Mistuh Fink, they have not invented a genre of picture that Bill Mayhew has not, at one time or othuh, been invited to essay. I have taken my stabs at the wrastlin' form, as I have stabbed at so many others, and with as little success. I gather that you are a fresh-man here, eager for an upperclassman's council. However, just at the moment... ...I have drinkin' to do. Why don't you stop at my bungalow, which is numbah fifteen, later on this afternoon... ...and we will discuss wrastlin' scenarios and other things lit'rary.

question: I'm sorry, I... My name is Fink... Uh, Bill asked me to drop by this afternoon. Is he in?
answer: HONEY!! WHERE'S M'HONEY!!

question: I am sorry, it's so embarassing.
answer: How about you? Will you be alright?

question: I'll be fine... Are you a writer, Mr Fink?
answer: Yes I am. I'm working on a wres  please call me Barton.

question: I'll tell Bill you dropped by. I'm sure he'll want to reschedule your appointment.
answer: Perhaps you and I could get together at some point also. I'm sorry if that sounds abrupt. I just... I don't know anyone here in this town.

question: Perhaps the three of us, Mr. Fink.
answer: Please, Barton.

question: Barton. You see, Barton, I'm not just Bill's secretary  Bill and I are... I love. We-
answer: I see.

question: ...I know this must look... funny.
answer: No, no

question: Howdy, neighbor.
answer: Charlie. How are you.

question: Jesus, I hope I'm not interrupting you again. I heard you walking around in here. Figured I'd drop by.
answer: Yeah, come in Charlie. Hadn't really gotten started yet  what happened to your ear?

question: Oh, yeah. An ear infection, chronic thing. Goes away for a while, but it always comes back. Gotta put cotton in it to staunch the flow of pus. Don't worry, it's not contagious.
answer: Seen a doctor?

question: Ah, doctors. What's he gonna tell me? Can't trade my head in for a new one.
answer: No, I guess you're stuck with the one you've got. Have a seat.

question: Thanks, I'd invite you over to my place, but it's a goddamn mess. You married, Bart?
answer: Nope.

question: I myself have yet to be lassoed. ...Got a sweetheart?
answer: No... I guess it's something about my work. I get so worked up over it, I don't know; I don't really have a lot of attention left over, so it would be a little unfair...

question: Yeah, the ladies do ask for attention. In my experience, they pretend to give it, but it's generally a smoke- screen for demanding it back  with interest. How about family, Bart? How're you fixed in that department?
answer: My folks live in Brooklyn, with my uncle.

question: Mine have passed on. It's just the three of us now... ...What's the expression  me myself and I.
answer: Sure, that's tough, but in a sense, we're all alone in this world aren't we Charlie? I'm often surrounded by family and friends, but...

question: Mm... You're no stranger to loneliness, then. I guess I got no beef; especially where the dames are concerned. In my line of work I get opportunities galore  always on the wing, you know what I'm saying. I could tell stories to curl your hair  but it looks like you've already heard 'em! ...That's me in Kansas City, plying my trade. ...It was taken by one of my policy holders. They're more than just customers to me, Barton. They really appreciate what I have to offer them. Ya see, her hubby was out of town at the time
answer: You know, in a way, I envy you Charlie. Your daily routine  you know what's expected. You know the drill. My job is to plumb the depths, so to speak, dredge something up from inside, something honest. There's no road map for that territory... ...and exploring it can be painful. The kind of pain most people don't know anything about. ...This must be boring you.

question: Not at all. It's damned interesting.
answer: Yeah... ...Probably sounds a little grand coming from someone who's writing a wrestling picture for Wallace Beery.

question: Beery! You got no beef there! He's good. Hell of an actor  though, for my money, you can't beat Jack Oakie. A stitch, Oakie. Funny stuff, funny stuff. But don't get me wrong  Beery, a wrestling picture, that could be a pip. Wrestled some myself back in school. I guess you know the basic moves.
answer: Nope, never watched any. I'm not that interested in the act itself

question: Okay, but hell, you should know what it is. I can show you in about thirty seconds. ...You're a little out of your weight class, but just for purposes of demonstration
answer: That's all right, really

question: Not a bit of it, compadre! Easiest thing in the world! You just get down on your knees to my left, slap your right hand here... ...and your left hand here. ...You can do it, champ! ...All right now, when I say "Ready... wrestle!" you try and pin me, and I try and pin you. That's the whole game. Got it?
answer: ...Yeah, okay.

question: Ready... wrestle! Damn, there I go again. We're gonna wake the downstairs neighbors. I didn't hurt ya, did I?
answer: It's okay, it's okay.

question: Well, that's all that wrestling is. Except usually there's more grunting and squirming before the pin. Well, it's your first time. And you're out of your weight class. ...Jesus, I did hurt you! ...I'm just a big, clumsy lug. I sure do apologize. ...You sure you're okay?
answer: I'm fine, Charlie. Really I am. Actually, it's been helpful, but I guess I should get back to work.

question: Look, maybe it's none of my business, but a man with your talent  don't you think your first obligation would be to your gift? Shouldn't you be doing whatever you have to do to work again?
answer: And what would that be, son?

question: I don't know exactly. But I do know what you're doing with that drink. You're cutting yourself off from your gift, and from me and Audrey, and from your fellow man, and from everything your art is about.
answer: No son, thisahere moonshine's got nothin' to do with shuttin' folks out. No, I'm usin' it to build somethin'.

question: What's that?
answer: I'm buildin' a levee. Gulp by gulp, brick by brick. Raisin' up a levee to keep that ragin' river of manure from lappin' at m'door.

question: That son of a bitch... Don't get me wrong, he's a fine writer.
answer: I'll jus' walk on down to the Pacific, and from there I'll... improvise.

question: Are you all right?
answer: Silent upon a hill in Darien!

question: Audrey, you can't put up with this.
answer: ...Oh Barton, I feel so... sorry for him!

question: What?! He's a son of a bitch!
answer: No, sometimes he just... well, he thinks about Estelle. His wife still lives in Fayettesville. She's... disturbed.

question: Really?... ...Well that doesn't excuse his behavior.
answer: He'll wander back when he's sober and apologize. He always does.

question: Okay, but that doesn't excuse his
answer: Barton. Empathy requires... understanding.

question: Looking quizzically at the page. What's wrong? He rises and answers the door.
answer: I hope these are your shoes.

question: Hi, Charlie.
answer: Because that would mean they gave you mine.

question: Yeah, as a matter of fact they did. Come on in.
answer: Jesus, what a day I've had. Ever had one of those days?

question: Seems like nothing but, lately.
answer: Jesus, what a day. Felt like I couldn't've sold ice water in the Sahara. Jesus. Okay, so you don't want insurance, so okay, that's your loss. But God, people can be rude. Feel like I have to talk to a normal person like just to restore a little of my...

question: Well, my pleasure. I could use a little lift myself.
answer: A little lift, yeah... ...Good thing they bottle it, huh pal? ...Did I say rude? People can be goddamn cruel. Especially some of their housewives. Okay, so I've got a weight problem. That's my cross to bear. I dunno...

question: Well it's... it's a defense mechanism.
answer: Defense against what? Insurance? Something they need? Something they should be thanking me for offering? A little peace of mind?... ...Finally decided to knock off early, take your advice. Went to see a doctor about this. ...He told me it was an ear infection. Ten dollars, please. I said, hell, I told YOU my ear was infected. Why don't YOU give ME ten dollars? Well, THAT led to an argument... ...Listen to me belly-achin'. As if my problems amounted to a hill of beans. How goes the life of the mind?

question: Well, it's been better. I can't seem to get going on this thing. That one idea, the one that lets you get started  I still haven't gotten it. Maybe I only had one idea in me  my play. Maybe once that was done, I was done being a writer. Christ, I feel like a fraud, sitting here staring at this paper.
answer: Those two love-birds next door drivin' you nuts?

question: How did you know about that?
answer: Know about it? I can practically see how they're doin' it. Brother, I wish I had a piece of that.

question: Yeah, but
answer: Seems like I hear everything that goes on in this dump. Pipes or somethin'. I'm just glad I don't have to ply MY trade in the wee-wee hours. ...Ah, you'll lick this picture business, believe me. You've got a head on your shoulders. What is it they say? Where there's a head, there's a hope?

question: Where there's life there's hope.
answer: That proves you really are a writer!

question: And there's hope for you too, Charlie. Tomorrow I bet you sell a half-dozen policies.
answer: Thanks, brother. But the fact is, I gotta pull up stakes temporarily.

question: You're leaving?
answer: In a few days. Out to your stompin' grounds as a matter of fact  New York City. Things have gotten all balled up at the Head Office.

question: I'm truly sorry to hear that, Charlie. I'll miss you.
answer: Well hell, buddy, don't pull a long face! This is still home for me  I keep my room, and I'll be back sooner or later... ...And  mark my words  by the time I get back you're picture'll be finished. I know it.

question: New York can be pretty cruel to strangers, Charlie. If you need a home-cooked meal you just look up Morris and Lillian Fink. They live on Fulton Street with my uncle Dave.
answer: Christ! ...Your room does that too?

question: I guess the heat's sweating off the wallpaper.
answer: What a dump... ...I guess it seems pathetic to a guy like you.

question: Well...
answer: Well it's pathetic, isn't it? I mean to a guy from New York.

question: What do you mean?
answer: This kind of heat. It's pathetic.

question: Well, I guess you pick your poison.
answer: So they say.

question: Don't pick up and leave without saying goodbye.
answer: Course not, compadre. You'll see me again.

question: Yeah. Fink. Come in. Wuddya got for me  what the hell happened to your face?
answer: Nothing. It's just a mosquito bite.

question: Like hell it is; there are no mosquitos in Los Angeles. Mosquitos breed in swamps  this is a desert town. Wuddya got for me?
answer: Well I...

question: On the Beery picture! Where are we? Wuddya got?
answer: Well, to tell you the truth, I'm having some trouble getting started

question: Getting STARTED! Christ Jesus! Started?! You mean you don't have ANYthing?!
answer: Well not much.

question: What do you think this is? HAMLET? GONE WITH THE WIND? RUGGLES OF RED GAP? It's a goddamn B picture! Big men in tights! You know the drill!
answer: I'm afraid I don't really understand that genre. maybe that's the prob-

question: Understand shit! I though you were gonna consult another writer on this!
answer: Well, I've talked to Bill Mayhew-

question: Bill Mayhew! Some help! The guy's a souse!
answer: He's a great writer

question: A souse!
answer: You don't understand. He's in pain, because he can't write-

question: Souse! Souse! He manages to write his name on the back of his paycheck every week!
answer: But... I thought no one cared about this picture.

question: You thought! Where'd you get THAT from? You thought! I don't know what the hell you said to Lipnik, but the sonofabitch LIKES you! You understand that, Fink? He LIKES you! He's taken an interest. NEVER make Lipnik like you. NEVER!
answer: I don't understand-

question: Are you deaf, he LIKES you! He's taken an interest! What the hell did you say to him?
answer: I didn't say anything-

question: Well he's taken an interest! That means he'll make your life hell, which I could care less about, but since I drew the short straw to supervise this turkey, he's gonna be all over me too! Fat-assed sonofabitch called me yesterday to ask how it's going  don't worry, I covered for you. Told him you were making progress and we were all very excited. I told him it was great, so now MY ass is on the line. He wants you to tell him all about it tomorrow.
answer: I can't write anything by tomorrow.

question: Who said write? Jesus, Jack can't read. You gotta TELL it to him-tell him SOMEthing for Chrissake.
answer: Well what do I tell him?

question: Hello, Chet, it's Barton Fink in 605. Can you try a number for me in Hollywood... Slausen 6-4304. Pick it up... Pick it up. Pick it-
answer: Hello.

question: Audrey, listen, I need help. I know it's late and I shouldn't be calling you like this  believe me I wouldn't have if I could see any other alternative, but I  I'm sorry - listen, how are you  I'm sorry. You doing okay?
answer: ...Who is this?

question: Hello, Barton.
answer: Audrey, thank you for coming. Thank you. I'm sorry to be such a... such a... Thank you.

question: Now that's all right, Barton. Everything'll be all right.
answer: Yes. Thank you. How's Bill?

question: Oh, he's... he drifted off. He'll sleep for a while now. What is it you have to do, exactly?
answer: Well I have to come up with  an outline, I'd guess you call it. The story. The whole goddamn story. Soup to nuts. Three acts. The whole goddamn-

question: It's alright, Barton. You don't have to write actual scenes?
answer: No, but the whole goddamn  Audrey? Have you ever had to read any of Bill's wrestling scenarios?

question: Yes, I'm afraid I have.
answer: What are they like? What are they about?

question: Well, usually, they're... simply morality tales. There's a good wrestler, and a bad wrestler whom he confronts at the end. In between, the good wrestler has a love interest or a child he has to protect. Bill would usually make the good wrestler a backwoods type, or a convict. And sometimes, instead of a waif, he'd have the wrestler protecting an idiot manchild. The studio always hated that. Oh, some of the scripts were so... spirited! ...Barton. ...Look, it's really just a formula. You don't have to type your soul into it. We'll invent some names and a new setting. I'll help you and it won't take any time at all. I did it for Bill so many times
answer: Did what for Bill?

question: Well... THIS.
answer: You wrote his scripts for him?

question: Well, the basic ideas were frequently his-
answer: You wrote Bill's scripts! Jesus Christ, you wrote his  what about before that?

question: Before what?
answer: Before Bill came to Hollywood.

question: Well, Bill was ALWAYS the author, so to speak-
answer: What do you mean so to speak?! Audrey, how long have you been his... secretary?

question: Barton, I think we should concentrate on OUR little project-
answer: I want to know how many of Bill's books you wrote!

question: Barton!
answer: I want to know!

question: Barton, honestly, only the last couple-
answer: Hah!

question: And my input was mostly... EDITORIAL, really, when he'd been drinking-
answer: I'll bet. Jesus  "The grand productive days." What a goddamn phony. ...W.P. Mayhew. William Goddamn Phony Mayhew. All his guff about escape. Hah! I'LL say he escaped! ...Well, we don't have much time.

question: It'll be fine... Don't judge him, Barton. Don't condescend to him... ...It's not as simple as you think. I helped Bill most by appreciating him, by understanding him. We all need understanding, Barton. Even you, tonight, it's all you really need...
answer: The hum of a mosquito brings us out of the black and we are looking down at Barton, in bed, asleep. It is dawn.

question: The hum of a mosquito brings us out of the black and we are looking down at Barton, in bed, asleep. It is dawn.
answer: The white ceiling. A humming black speck flits across the white.

question: Slowly, cautiously, he props himself up, his look following the sound of the mosquito.
answer: Audrey lies facing away on her side of the bed, half covered by a blanket.

question: Gingerly, he reaches over and draws the blanket down Audrey's back.
answer: The alabaster white of Audrey's back. His hand is dripping with blood. Too much blood.

question: Barton. Are you all right?
answer: No... Can I come in?

question: Why don't we go to your room-
answer: Charlie, I'm in trouble. You've gotta help me.

question: Get a grip on yourself, brother. Whatever the problem is, we'll sort it out.
answer: Charlie, I'm in trouble  something horrible's happened  I've gotta call the police... ...Will you stay with me till they get here?

question: Don't worry about it, Barton. We can sort it-
answer: Before you go in  I didn't do this. I don't know how it happened, but I didn't... I want you to know that...

question: Jesus... Jesus... Jesus have mercy... ...Jesus, Barton, what the hell is this? What're we gonna do?
answer: I've gotta call the police  or you could call for me

question: Hold on
answer: You gotta believe me

question: Hold on
answer: I didn't do this, I did NOT do this

question: Hold on. Stop. Take a deep breath. Tell me what happened.
answer: I don't know! I woke up, she was... God, you gotta believe me!

question: I believe you, brother, but this don't look good.
answer: We gotta call the police

question: Hold on. I said hold on, so hold on.
answer: Yeah.

question: What do you think happened?
answer: I don't know! Maybe it was her... boyfriend. I passed out. I don't know. Won't the police be able to

question: Stop with the police! Wake up, friend! This does not look good! They hang people for this!
answer: But I didn't do it  don't you believe me?

question: I believe you  I KNOW you. But why should the police? ...Did you... Barton, between you and me, did you have sexual intercourse? Jesus... They can tell that...
answer: They GOTTA believe me, Charlie! They gotta have mercy!

question: Bart! So happy to see ya! Sit! Talk! Relax for a minute, then talk! Drink?
answer: Yeah... rye whiskey?

question: Boy! You writers! Work hard, play hard! That's what I hear, anyway... ... Lou. Anyway. Ben Geisler tells me things're going along great. Thinks we've got a real winner in this one. And let me tell you something, I'm counting on it. I've taken an interest. Not to interfere, mind you  hardly seems necessary in your case. A writer  a storyteller  of your stature. Givitta me in bold strokes, Bart. Gimme the broad outlines. I'm sitting in the audience, the lights go down, Capitol logo comes up... you're on!
answer: Yeah, okay... well... we fade in... ...It's a tenement building. On the Lower East Side...

question: Great! He's poor, this wrestler! He's had to struggle!
answer: And then... well... ...Can I be honest, Mr. Lipnik?

question: CAN you? You damn well better be. Jesus, if I hadn't been honest in my business dealings  well, of course, you can't always be honest, not with the sharks swimming around this town  but if you're a writer, you don't think about those things  if I'd been totally honest, I wouldn't be within a mile of this pool  unless I was cleaning it. But that's no reason for you not to be. Honest, I mean. Not cleaning the pool.
answer: Well... to be honest, I'm never really comfortable discussing a work in progress. I've got it all worked out in my head, but sometimes if you force it out in words  prematurely  the wrong words  well, your meaning changes, and it changes your own mind, and you never get it back  so I'd just as soon not talk about it.

question: I  Mr. Lipnik
answer: KISS THIS MAN'S FEET!! ...Okay, get out of here. You're fired, you understand me? Get out of my sight.

question: Mr. Lipnik, I
answer: I apologize, Barton.

question: No no, Mr. Breeze has actually been a great help
answer: You don't have to cover for him. It's noble of you, but these things happen in business.

question: Mr. Lipnik, I really would feel much better if you could reconsider
answer: Ah, forget it, kid. I want you to pull this out of your head. If that sonofabitch wouldn't apologize to you, goddammit, I will. I respect your artistry and your methods, and if you can't fill us in yet, well hell, we should be kissing your feet for your fine efforts. ...You know in the old country we were taught, as very young children, that there's no shame in supplicatin' yourself when you respect someone. ...On behalf of Capitol Pictures, the administration, and all a the stockholders, please accept this as a symbol of our apology and respect.

question: Barton. Can I come in?
answer: Jesus... You're leaving.

question: Have to, old timer. Just for a while.
answer: Jesus, Charlie, I...

question: Everything's okay, believe me. I know it's rough mentally, but everything's taken care of.
answer: Charlie! I've got no one else here! You're the only person I know in Los Angeles... ...that I can talk to.

question: It's okay... It's okay...
answer: Charlie, I feel like I'm going crazy  like I'm losing my mind. I don't know what to do... I didn't do it, believe me. I'm sure of that, Charlie. I just... ...I just don't know what... to do

question: You gotta get a grip on, brother. You gotta just carry on  just for a few days, till I get back. Try and stay here, keep your door locked. Don't talk to anyone. We just gotta keep our heads and we'll figure it out.
answer: Yeah, but Charlie

question: Dammit, don't argue with me. You asked me to believe you  well I do. Now don't argue with me. ...Look, pal  can you do something for me? ...Keep this for me, till I get back. ...It's just personal stuff. I don't wanna drag it with me, but I don't trust 'em downstairs, and I'd like to think it's in good hands.
answer: Sure, Charlie.

question: Funny, huh, when everything that's important to a guy, everything he wants to keep from a lifetime  when he can fit it into a little box like that. I guess... I guess it's kind of pathetic.
answer: It's more than I've got.

question: Well, keep it for me. Maybe it'll bring you good luck. Yeah, it'll help you finish your script. You'll think about me... ...Make me your wrestler. Then you'll lick that story of yours.
answer: Thanks, Charlie.

question: Yeah, well, see you soon, friend. You're gonna be fine.
answer: You'll be back?

question: Funny. As in, he likes to ventilate people with a shotgun and then cut their heads off.
answer: Yeah, he's funny that way.

question: Started in Kansas City. Couple of housewives.
answer: Couple of days ago we see the same M.O. out in Los Feliz.

question: Doctor. Ear, nose and throat man,.
answer: All of which he's now missin'.

question: Well, some of his throat was there.
answer: Physician, heal thyself.

question: Good luck with no fuckin' head.
answer: Anyway.

question: Hollywood precinct finds another stiff yesterday. Not too far from here. This one's better looking than the doc.
answer: Female caucasian, thirty years old. Nice tits. No head. You ever see Mundt with anyone meets that description?

question: Garland, it's me.
answer: Barton? What time is it? Are you all right?

question: Yeah, I'm fine, Garland  I have to talk to you. I'm calling long distance.
answer: Okay. ...It's Barton. Calling long distance. ...What is it Barton? Are you okay?

question: I'm fine, garland, but I have to talk with you.
answer: Go ahead, son.

question: It's about what I'm writing, Garland. It's really... I think it's really big.
answer: What do you mean, Barton?

question: Not big in the sense of large  although it's that too. I mean important. This may be the most IMPORTANT work I've done.
answer: Well, I'm... glad to hear that

question: Very important, Garland. I just thought you should know that. Whatever happens.
answer: ...That's fine.

question: Have you read the Bible, Garland?
answer: ...Barton, is everything okay?

question: Yes... Isn't it?
answer: Well, I'm just asking. You sound a little

question: Sound a little what?
answer: Well, you just... sound a little

question: You made morning papers, Fink.
answer: Second one of your friends to end up dead.

question: You didn't tell us you knew the dame.
answer: Sixth floor too high for you, Fink?

question: How you been, buddy? ...Don't look at me like that, neighbor. It's just me  Charlie.
answer: I hear it's Mundt. Madman Mundt.

question: Jesus, people can be cruel... ...if it's not my build, it's my personality. ...They say I'm a madman, Barton, but I'm not mad at anyone. Honest I'm not. Most guys I just feel sorry for. Yeah. It tears me up inside, to think about what they're going through. How trapped they are. I understand it. I feel for 'em. So I try and help them out... ...Jesus. Yeah. I know what it feels like, when things get all balled up at the head office. It puts you through hell, Barton. So I help people out. I just wish someone would do as much for me... ...Jesus it's hot. Sometimes it gets so hot, I wanna crawl right out of my skin.
answer: But Charlie  why me? Why

question: Because you DON'T LISTEN! ...Jesus, I'm dripping again. ...C'mon Barton, you think you know about pain? You think I made your life hell? Take a look around this dump. You're just a tourist with a typewriter, Barton. I live here. Don't you understand that... ...And you come into MY home... And you complain that I'M making too... much... noise.
answer: ...I'm sorry.

question: Fink! Morris or Lillian Fink! Eighty- five Fulton Street! Or Uncle Dave!
answer: Fink.

question: Mr. Lipnik.
answer: Colonel Lipnik, if you don't mind. ...Siddown. ...I was commissioned yesterday in the Army Reserve. Henry Morgenthau arranged it. He's a dear friend.

question: Congratulations.
answer: Actually it hasn't officially gone through yet. Had wardrobe whip this up. You gotta pull teeth to get anything done in this town. I can understand a little red tape in peacetime, but now it's all-out warfare against the Japs. Little yellow bastards. They'd love to see me sit this one out.

question: Yes sir, they
answer: Anyway, I had Lou read your script for me. ...I gotta tell you, Fink. It won't wash.

question: With all due respect, sir, I think it's the best work I've done.
answer: Don't gas me, Fink. If you're opinion mattered, then I guess I'd resign and let YOU run the the studio. It doesn't and you won't, and the lunatics are not going to run THIS particular asylum. So let's put a stop to THAT rumor right now.

question: Yes sir.
answer: I had to call Beery this morning, let him know we were pushing the picture back. After all I'd told him about quality, about that Barton Fink feeling. How disappointed we were. Wally was heartbroken. The man was devastated. He was  well, I didn't actually call him, Lou did. But that's a fair description, isn't it Lou?

question: I had to call Beery this morning, let him know we were pushing the picture back. After all I'd told him about quality, about that Barton Fink feeling. How disappointed we were. Wally was heartbroken. The man was devastated. He was  well, I didn't actually call him, Lou did. But that's a fair description, isn't it Lou?
answer: Yes, Colonel.

question: Hell, I could take you through it step by step, explain why your story stinks, but I won't insult your intelligence. Well all right, first of all
answer: "Blood, Sweat, and Canvas".

question: Look at "Blood, Sweat, and Canvas". These are big movies, Fink. About big men, in tights  both physically and mentally. But especially physically. We don't put Wallace Beery in some fruity movie about suffering  I thought we were together on that.
answer: I'm sorry if I let you down.

question: You didn't let ME down. Or even Lou. We don't live or die by what you scribble, Fink. You let Ben Geisler down. He liked you. Trusted you. And that's why he's gone. Fired. That guy had a heart as big as the outdoors, and you fucked him. He tried to convince me to fire you too, but that would be too easy. No, you're under contract and you're gonna stay that way. Anything you write will be the property of Capitol Pictures. And Capitol Pictures will not produce anything you write. Not until you grow up a little. You ain't no writer, Fink  you're a goddamn write-off.
answer: I tried to show you something beautiful. Something about all of US

question: You arrogant sonofabitch! You think you're the only writer who can give me that Barton Fink feeling?! I got twenty writers under contract that I can ask for a Finktype thing from. You swell-headed hypocrite! You just don't get it, do you? You think the whole world revolves inside whatever rattles inside that little kike head of yours. Get him outta my sight, Lou. Make sure he stays in town, though; he's still under contract. I want you in town, Fink, and outta my sight. Now get lost. There's a war on.
answer: He walks a few more paces and sits down on the sand, looking out to see. His gaze shifts to one side.
